David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him." Then you were asked: "How willing would you be to spend an evening socializing with David?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unwilling and 5 means Very willing, nothing else.

David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Demographics: Age: 78; Gender: Female; Education: Vocational/tech school/some college/associates; Income: 20-29K; Employment: Retired; Political affiliation: Strong Democrat; Ideology: Very Liberal

Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. About a year ago, David was prescribed prescription pain medication. He took the pain medication regularly, and after a few weeks found that he increasingly felt the desire for more, even though his pain had improved. David went to several different doctors to get more prescriptions from them and then started getting them from a friend. Each time David tried to cut down, he felt anxious and became sweaty and nauseated for hours on end and also could not sleep. These symptoms lasted until he resumed taking the prescription pain medication. David’s friends complained that he had become unreliable – making plans one day and canceling them the next. His family said he had changed and that they could no longer count on him. David has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with opioid use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him. The doctor also thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David will be able to live a full life, such as having a steady job, a stable romantic relationship, and an engaged social life?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.

David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia." Then you were asked: "How willing would you be to make friends with David?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unwilling and 5 means Very willing, nothing else.

David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him." Then you were asked: "How willing would you be to make friends with David?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unwilling and 5 means Very willing, nothing else.

Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. About a year ago, David was prescribed prescription pain medication. He took the pain medication regularly, and after a few weeks found that he increasingly felt the desire for more, even though his pain had improved. David went to several different doctors to get more prescriptions from them and then started getting them from a friend. Each time David tried to cut down, he felt anxious and became sweaty and nauseated for hours on end and also could not sleep. These symptoms lasted until he resumed taking the prescription pain medication. David’s friends complained that he had become unreliable – making plans one day and canceling them the next. His family said he had changed and that they could no longer count on him. David has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with opioid use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him. The doctor also thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David would do something violent to himself?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.

Each time David tried to cut down, he felt anxious and became sweaty and nauseated for hours on end and also could not sleep. These symptoms lasted until he resumed taking the prescription pain medication. David’s friends complained that he had become unreliable – making plans one day and canceling them the next. His family said he had changed and that they could no longer count on him. David has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with opioid use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him. The doctor also thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David’s condition will improve with proper treatment?" instruction: You are a behavioral prediction model. Given demographic information about a participant and an experimental scenario, predict how they would respond.
input:
Demographics: Age: 34; Gender: Male; Education: High school graduate or equivalent; Income: 50-74K; Employment: Employed as paid employee; Political affiliation: Moderate Republican; Ideology: Moderate

Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. Up until a year ago, life was pretty okay for David. But then, things started to change. He thought that people around him were making disapproving comments and talking behind his back. David was convinced that people were spying on him and that they could hear what he was thinking. David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David would do something violent to himself?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.

Demographics: Age: 30; Gender: Male; Education: Bachelor's degree; Income: 125-149K; Employment: Employed as paid employee; Political affiliation: Moderate Democrat; Ideology: Somewhat Liberal

Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. For the last two weeks, David has been feeling really down. He wakes up in the morning with a flat, heavy feeling that sticks with him all day long. He isn't enjoying things the way he normally would. In fact, nothing seems to give David pleasure. Even when good things happen, they don't seem to make David happy. He pushes on through his days, but it is really hard. The smallest tasks are difficult to accomplish. He finds it hard to concentrate on anything. He feels out of energy and out of steam. And even though David feels tired when night comes, he can't get to sleep. David feels pretty worthless, and very discouraged. David’s family has noticed that he hasn't been himself for about the last month, and that he has pulled away from them. David just doesn't feel like talking. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with major depressive disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him. The doctor also thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David would do something violent to himself?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.

David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him." Then you were asked: "How willing would you be to spend an evening socializing with David?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unwilling and 5 means Very willing, nothing else.

David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David would do something violent to other people?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.

Each time he tried to cut down, he became very agitated, sweaty and he couldn't sleep, so he took another drink. His family has complained that he is often hung-over, and has become unreliable – making plans one day, and canceling them the next. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with alcohol use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him. The doctor also thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries." Then you were asked: "How willing would you be to spend an evening socializing with David?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unwilling and 5 means Very willing, nothing else.

David went to several different doctors to get more prescriptions from them and then started getting them from a friend. Each time David tried to cut down, he felt anxious and became sweaty and nauseated for hours on end and also could not sleep. These symptoms lasted until he resumed taking the prescription pain medication. David’s friends complained that he had become unreliable – making plans one day and canceling them the next. His family said he had changed and that they could no longer count on him. David has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with opioid use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. Up until a year ago, life was pretty okay for David. But then, things started to change. He thought that people around him were making disapproving comments and talking behind his back. David was convinced that people were spying on him and that they could hear what he was thinking. David lost his drive to participate in his usual work and family activities and retreated to his home, eventually spending most of his day in his room. David became so preoccupied with what he was thinking that he skipped meals and stopped bathing regularly. At night, when everyone else was sleeping, he was walking back and forth in his room. David was hearing voices even though no one else was around. These voices told him what to do and what to think. He has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with schizophrenia. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries." Then you were asked: "How willing would you be to spend an evening socializing with David?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unwilling and 5 means Very willing, nothing else.

Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. About a year ago, David was prescribed prescription pain medication. He took the pain medication regularly, and after a few weeks found that he increasingly felt the desire for more, even though his pain had improved. David went to several different doctors to get more prescriptions from them and then started getting them from a friend. Each time David tried to cut down, he felt anxious and became sweaty and nauseated for hours on end and also could not sleep. These symptoms lasted until he resumed taking the prescription pain medication. David’s friends complained that he had become unreliable – making plans one day and canceling them the next. His family said he had changed and that they could no longer count on him. David has been living this way for six months. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with opioid use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be related to the fact that a little over a year ago, David was in a car accident with his best friend who died a week later from his injuries. When explaining the results of his evaluation to David, the doctor suggested that David consider a course of mental health treatment that is known to be helpful in treating David’s condition." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David would do something violent to other people?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.

Scenario: You read the following description: "David is a White man who has completed high school. During the last month, David has started to drink more than his usual amount of alcohol. In fact, he has noticed that he needs to drink twice as much as he used to get the same effect. Several times, he has tried to cut down, or stop drinking, but he can't. Each time he tried to cut down, he became very agitated, sweaty and he couldn't sleep, so he took another drink. His family has complained that he is often hung-over, and has become unreliable – making plans one day, and canceling them the next. Because he has been having these problems, David was evaluated by a doctor who diagnosed him with alcohol use disorder. While the doctor does not know for sure why David has developed his condition, he thinks it may be genetic because David’s father, his father’s father, and his aunt on his mother’s side are all very similar to him." Then you were asked: "In your opinion, how likely is it that David would do something violent to other people?" Only return an integer from 1 to 5, where 1 means Very unlikely and 5 means Very likely, nothing else.
